image.altText: A man in a suit is interviewed for television.

items.synopsis: One of the taxpayers helped by ATO whistleblower Richard Boyle has spoken out for the first time, describing the prosecution of the person who gave him a lifeline as "insanity". Mr Boyle's wife has also spoken to 7.30 about the toll the six-year-long ordeal has taken on the couple.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces the prospect of four decades in jail. His wife says all he did was tell the truth

image.altText: A bushfire burning in a Queensland national park

items.synopsis: Queensland authorities are bracing for dangerous fire conditions, with seven districts facing the likelihood of high fire danger by the end of this week. Four fires blazed across the state yesterday, damaging properties and causing some residents to flee their homes.

title.children: After a fiery weekend in Queensland, bushfire warnings are set to intensify this week

image.altText: A Wallabies player with his hand over his face after losing to Fiji at the men's 2023 Rugby World Cup.

items.synopsis: Australia's Rugby World Cup campaign is dealt a major blow, with Fiji defeating the Wallabies in a tense pool match in Saint-Étienne.

title.children: Wallabies' Rugby World Cup hopes take massive hit after stunning loss to Fiji

image.altText: One man wears a cap and blue check shirt and jeans smiling, another in denim jacket and shoulder length hair, smiling

items.synopsis: One of Australia's biggest rock bands, Silverchair ended with a whimper, not a bang. And so too did their friendships … almost.

title.children: 'We should have gone out in a blaze of glory': What really tore Silverchair apart

image.altText: A profile picture of UK comedian Russell Brand

items.synopsis: Britain's BBC says it is "urgently looking into the issues" raised by allegations of sexual assault made against the broadcaster's former employee, British comedian and actor Russell Brand, who denies the accusations.

title.children: BBC investigating after sexual assault allegations made against Russell Brand

image.altText: build-to-rent tenant Carly Hulls

items.synopsis: Build-to-rent developments are new to Australia but with long leases and freedom to have pets and make alterations they are being tipped as an answer to the rental crisis. But affordability remains a problem, writes Angelique Lu

title.children: Carly needed a stable rental home to raise her baby. A build-to-rent scheme was the answer

image.altText: Eddie JOnes looks past a Wallabies player

items.synopsis: The Wallabies' loss to Fiji for the first time in 69 years has left their Rugby World Cup hopes on a precipice, with penalties and ill discipline costing them dearly. But it could have been worse. Here are five quick hits from Fiji's momentous victory.

title.children: Five quick hits — Penalties, squad questions and a 'massively important' bonus point as Wallabies lose to Fiji

image.altText: Two quinoa salad bowls with sweet potato, baby spinach, tinned tuna, pine nuts and red onion to illustrate our simple recipe.

items.synopsis: The average Australian diet barely scraped a pass on the healthy diet score card, with most adults eating too few veg and too much junk.

title.children: The CSIRO says we're eating too much junk and not enough veges — here's how to improve your diet

image.altText: Woman holding open an empty pink wallet

items.synopsis: Family courts have never formerly acknowledged the financial impacts of abuse when dividing assets. But there are growing calls to better consider the devastating reality.

title.children: Calls to reform laws to stop DV survivors walking out with 'absolutely nothing'

image.altText: The Voice to Parliament referendum booklet opened to the pages outlining how the Yes and No arguments will appear

items.synopsis: Unlike federal elections, a majority of Australian states will need to support the Voice to Parliament in order for the change to pass.

title.children: A double majority is needed for the Voice referendum to pass. What does that mean and how does it work?

image.altText: Emma Grant walking with students out the doors of the school.

items.synopsis: Poor mental health and excessive screen time are the biggest problems facing young people, according to a new survey of more than 2,000 Australian teachers. New resources will be made available for teachers in a hope to create more conversations on mental wellbeing.

title.children: 'Missing some of those socio-emotional skills': Teachers say mental health is the biggest problem facing young people

image.altText: A composite photo of Wang Yi and Jake Sullivan.

items.synopsis: White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan meets with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi in Malta for 12 hours over two days, as the world's two largest economies seek to stabilise troubled relations.

title.children: US and Chinese representatives hold lengthy meetings in Malta amid strained ties and mutual suspicion

image.altText: Kaden Groves sprays champagne

items.synopsis: Kaden Groves wins the final stage of this year's final grand tour, the Vuelta a España, in a dramatic sprint finish in Madrid as Sepp Kuss seals victory ahead of Tour de France champion Jonas Vingegaard in a Jumbo-Visma clean sweep of the podium.

title.children: Aussie sprinter joins select group at Vuelta a España

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

items.synopsis: The Australian sharemarket is set for a weaker start as investors wait for foreign central banks' next interest rates meetings, while Michele Bullock begins her first seven-year term as RBA governor. Follow live.

title.children: New dawn at the RBA as Michele Bullock begins as governor, ASX set for weak start ahead of overseas interest rates meetings

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has released new figures to try and shut down growing calls to introduce nuclear power into Australia's future energy mix from the Opposition. The government's current plan is to invest in clean energy projects through what's known as "Rewiring the Nation" at a cost of $20 billion. But the Opposition has argued nuclear is cheaper and more reliable. Energy Minister Chris Bowen says new analysis shows introducing nuclear power to replace retiring coal-fired power stations would cost $387 billion. "The opposition is proposing small modular reactors, which are 300 mega watts each which means you need a lot of them to replace the retiring coal fired power," he said. "In fact, you need 71 of these reactors to r eplace 21 gigawatts of coal fire power we have in the system. "Its a unicorn and a fantasy."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'A unicorn and a fantasy':  Energy minister blasts Coalition's calls to introduce nuclear power

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In a statement posted on the ASX, the Commonwealth Bank says the Federal Court has approved a $50 million settlement sum over a consumer credit insurance (CCI) class action launched in June 2020. The $50 million settlement sum is in line with what CBA announced on November 14 last year. The CCI class action related to consumer credit insurance for credit cards and personal loans sold between January 1, 2010 and March 7, 2018. According to Slater and Gordon, which was behind the class action, claimed CBA: caused customers to make payments as a result of a mis,taken belief their policy was compulsory or provided value to them engaged in misleading or deceptive conduct in relation to the sale of the policies to customers, engaged in unconscionable conduct in relation to the sale and issue of the policies to customers by, among other things, selling or issuing policies with no or little value, unlawfully provided personal advice to some customers who purchased the policies in a bank branch or over the telephone.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: $50m settlement approved over Commonwealth Bank's consumer credit insurance class action

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It feels like we've been talking about it forever, but today is day one of Michele Bullock's seven-year term as RBA governor. She's officially taken over from Philip Lowe, who left the central bank at the end of last week after a seven-year term as governor himself, on top of decades spent working there in various roles. As for how the RBA will see its new dawn, it'll be a pretty muted affair. We're still two weeks away from the RBA's next meeting on interest rates (October 3, if you haven't got it in the diary). But the RBA will release the minutes from its most recent meeting earlier this month, when the central bank barely shifted the dial from its monetary policy stance in its August meeting. As for who is set to replace Michele Bullock as deputy governor ? There's no word yet, although the search is thought to be continuing.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: It's Michele Bullock's first day as RBA governor

image.altText: A close up of a dead snake with green eyes

items.synopsis: A 10-year-old boy became the first recipient of taipan antivenom in 1955 and survived. But there was no such luck for Kevin Budden, who captured the first snake of its kind for milking five years earlier, but died in the process.

title.children: When Bruce was bitten by a taipan as a child, his life was saved thanks to a reptile enthusiast who paid the ultimate price

image.altText: Laptop on desk with chatGPT displayed on screen

items.synopsis: Tools driven by artificial intelligence are being used by jobseekers to put together their applications. But recruiters warn misusing them could hinder chances of landing a dream role.

title.children: Using ChatGPT to write your resume and cover letter could backfire. Here's how to use it wisely

image.altText: A white woman with short hair holds a white dog on a verandah

items.synopsis: Most Australians are aware of the risk of natural disasters, not all of us actually prepare. But some are leading the way, having their suitcases packed with essentials, their properties cleared of fuel and learning how to fight fires.

title.children: 'Evacuate now': When Sarah got to the evacuation centre, she realised she'd forgotten to bring so much

image.altText: For Rent sign

items.synopsis: The one-bedroom apartment was advertised as a delightful ground-floor apartment with its own private courtyard. Within a day the price was raised twice due to increased market interest.

title.children: It was advertised as a delightful ground-floor apartment. Within a day, the rental price had gone up twice

image.altText: Woman holding a crate full of bottles, with two big green bags in front of her

items.synopsis: With no yellow-lidded recycling bins for hundreds of kilometres, what do people in rural and remote areas do to reduce their waste? People like Longreach's Patsy Worland help, but it's an uphill battle.

title.children: Why can't people in outback Queensland recycle? There are three main reasons

image.altText: Smoke surrounds a building.

items.synopsis: An 18-storey building in the centre of Sudan's capital is engulfed in flames as fighting between the military and a rival paramilitary force enters its sixth month.

title.children: Fire engulfs 18-storey tower block in Sudan's capital as rival forces battle

image.altText: A numbat in the wild.

items.synopsis: Four juvenile numbats have been spotted at Secret Rocks for the first time, sparking new hope for the region's reintroduction program.

title.children: Fenced in from predators, these numbats are thrilling ecologists as they repopulate the Eyre Peninsula

image.altText: Black and white photo of two men together one in suit and one in jersey

items.synopsis: Born in Tweed Heads, Morgan was the first Indigenous player to play for Australia in rugby league and the first Indigenous Australian to represent the nation in any major code.

title.children: 'An inspiration and trailblazer': Indigenous rugby league player Lionel Morgan dies, aged 85

image.altText: A snowman melting

items.synopsis: Snow enthusiasts are becoming increasingly concerned about what climate change will do to Australia's alpine regions.

title.children: Snowboarders, skiers fear for the future of their playground as worst snow season in decades wraps up

image.altText: Drew Barrymore with an upset expression recording a video.

items.synopsis: Drew Barrymore's initial decision to return to the air on Monday without her three union writers and with picketers outside her studio was met with criticism.

title.children: Drew Barrymore postpones return of daytime talk show until after Hollywood strikes

image.altText: Pope Pius XII raises his right hand in a papal blessing at the Vatican.

items.synopsis: The correspondence, found by Vatican archivists, contradicts the Holy See's official position at the time that the information it had about the gas chamber atrocities were unverified.

title.children: Wartime Pope likely knew about Nazi concentration camps, unearthed letter reveals

image.altText: Norman standing in his home with cleaning products behind him.

items.synopsis: Elder Norman Frank Jupurrurla has been forced to leave his public housing twice in six months following bed bug outbreaks at his home in Village Camp, a community living area on the outskirts of Tennant Creek.

title.children: 'It's like hell': Bed bug outbreaks have caused Norm to lose his home twice in six months

image.altText: propeller airplane with REX logo sits on tarmac at dusk.

items.synopsis: Local governments own and operate hundreds of airports around the country, but many operate at a loss and rely on ratepayers to stay in the air. Councils say more funding is needed to support their community's "valuable asset".

title.children: 'Too crucial to fail': Why your local council is likely funding an airport that isn't profitable

image.altText: Donald Trump speaks at a podium wearing a dark suit and blue tie

items.synopsis: Speaking to religious leaders in Washington, the presumptive Republican nominee for next year's US presidential election questions Joe Biden's cognitive ability, but gets mixed up when talking about world wars and his political rivals.

title.children: 'I'm leading Obama by a lot': Donald Trump appears to get his political rivals mixed up, warns of World War II

image.altText: Marco Jansen hits out

items.synopsis: Australia's ODI series against South Africa has ended in another lopsided defeat, as Australia go from leading the series 2-0 to losing three straight matches ahead of the World Cup in India next month.

title.children: Australia suffer another heavy defeat, lose ODI series to South Africa

image.altText: A 60-something man in a dark suits clasps his hands on a stage

items.synopsis: The 77-year-old had made comments that were seen as disparaging toward black and female musicians on a publicity tour to promote his new book, The Masters, that featured only white and male artists.

title.children: Rolling Stone co-founder removed from Rock Hall of Fame board

image.altText: An exhausted F1 driver in a red racing suit, sticks his tongue out in celebration

items.synopsis: Ferrari driver Carlos Sainz produces a tactical masterclass to win the Singapore Grand Prix.

title.children: Red Bull finally beaten as Sainz produces Ferrari masterclass

image.altText: Danielle Laidley sits in a studio, a makeup artist is doing touch up as Danielle prepares for the camera.

items.synopsis: AFL star Danielle Laidley's life spiralled when she was arrested in 2020 over accusations of stalking while battling a drug addiction. Now she is taking the reins and revealing it all, in her own words, in a new documentary.

title.children: Former AFL star Danielle Laidley tells her story — 'nothing more, nothing less'

image.altText: Having a cup of coffee with their dog on the verandah.

items.synopsis: After swapping their demanding jobs and cosmopolitan life in inner Melbourne for a bush block in Queensland, Jennifer Nini and Ben McGuire haven't looked back.

title.children: Leaving city crowds behind, this couple has found contentment by flower farming in country Queensland
